all right hello folks my name is daniel mangum i'm presenting today with sasha grennert sasha is a tech lead for sig release
and i am the ci signal lead which we'll get into what that means later on for the 1.19 kubernetes release we're
going to give a talk today about how we do kubernetes releases um this is
as you see um as you'll see on the slides in just a moment this is part one of a talk and we are
going to be giving part two at kubecon eu which is also virtual and i guess just a few weeks after this
airs um so we're excited to kind of give a nice introduction to this and then go into some more depth so we hope you tune in for that one um
as well so i'm gonna go ahead and share my screen here and we can get right into it all right
so like i said today we're talking about anatomy of a kubernetes release success through team and tools so a big
part of releasing kubernetes is a lot of folks that come together to have individual tasks that then roll
up to this kind of big operation that results in new kubernetes releases being available for
the community and we try to automate a lot of that through tools but there's also a lot of individuals spread out all over the
world who do a lot of work to make this happen so to kind of give you an overview of
what we're going to talk about today we're going to first just look at how kubernetes releases are made in general
just logistically then we'll provide an overview about the uh siegeless special interest
group um which uh sasha and i are both a part of um and then we'll deep dive into the
actual 1.19 release cycle i'm excited to talk about this today and sasha is going to give us a lot of
detail on it because 1.19 is a little bit unique because of the
global pandemic pandemic situation and how some of the timeline has to be
adjusted and how that's affected subsequent releases and that sort of thing so i'm excited to kind of go through how
uh the the group work together to accommodate uh this changing times that we're living in right now so this
will be a especially unique cycle to look at all right so looking at just an overview
of the kubernetes release cycle um at the start of the release cycle the first thing you have to do is is build
the release team so um as we'll get into a moment uh one of the i think most thriving parts of the
kubernetes community is the sig release shadow program so essentially there are different teams as
part of sig release and they all do different things to make a release happen and there's an application process for
you to become a shadow of a given team so each team has a lead and then there's usually three or
four shadows um so at the beginning the first thing you want to do is establish the leads which are typically shadows or previous
leads from previous releases and then you'll look through the applications for all of
the shadow applicants and select them for the different teams after that you need to go ahead and set
the schedule for the release so as sasha sasha's going to get into later there's different deadlines for
different parts of the release and those need to be set so that people who are actually implementing features
into kubernetes know when they had to have that implemented and merged or have that reviewed and then after
that you go ahead and start tracking the things that have to be done by each of those deadlines um and that's where the sig release team definitely
comes into play quite a bit um and then throughout the cycle um we have continuous updates starting
on a weekly basis and then getting into more granular and then there's also intermediate releases so alpha beta and rc releases
that's done by the release engineering subgroup another group that sasha and i are both a part of and he's going to talk about that a
little bit more all right so looking at some of those deadlines that i mentioned uh the first
thing is enhancements freeze so if you're not familiar with how new features get added to kubernetes
you have to create a kepp um so a kubernetes enhancement proposal um so basically this is just a write-up
you know in markdown in a github repository and that has to be approved by folks in
the sig that that's related to so for instance this cycle outside of our sig release duties
um sasha and i worked on implementing uh set comp ga so moving some of the set comp
functionality to a general availability it was currently being used with alpha fields so um one of
our our co-workers on that apollo actually wrote up a cap or modified an
existing cap to show how we're going to implement that and then that had to be accepted before we went about actually
doing the implementation burn down is when we move from those
weekly release meetings where each of the teams are giving updates to having more granular release meetings
so that typically looks like three times a week and then eventually right up close to the
release time potentially every day and those that's just where um leads and shadows from the different
teams within sig release will give updates on their status which help inform how we're moving towards a
release next after that is the docs deadline so you have to imagine for new features we
have to document them at least most of them especially if they're user facing and for the docs deadline the docs team
which is one of the sig release kind of sub teams make sure that all of the prs for docs
are in place and that they can be reviewed so that they can quickly be merged later on um code freeze is probably the
biggest thing that you've heard about if you follow any kubernetes folks on twitter or anything like that so code freeze is
exactly what it sounds like you can't merge any more code um into the release
branch um so you have to have code complete you have to have your pr's open um they have to be approved um and then
merged um this this cycle in particular we had some issues with ci
so we always work around that to make sure that things that are complete are able to be included in
the release but generally you have to have things merged by that date cherry pick deadline basically means
that no more changes can go into the release branch so you can imagine after code freeze cherry picks have to happen from the
main branch onto the release branch but we also have a deadline for for when that can be done and those are usually
for fixing critical bugs or fixing a test that's failing or something like that and then finally we culminate in release
day um so this is exactly what it sounds like um it's just the day that we make the release and
there's a lot of celebration for all the hard work that folks have done i want to mention here at the bottom we
have some links um to the sig release repo sig release is where you have handbooks
for each of the roles that folks play in the release as well as the calendar for all previous
and current releases um so that's definitely very helpful for folks that are looking to get a little more
in depth of a look than we could give in a talk of this length all right so we talked about these
different teams for sig release and i'll briefly give an overview of each of them some of them i have more
context on than others but we'll start off with the team lead so the team lead kind of oversees all of
the release so they're running the release team meetings and they're getting updates and making sure everything is
happening happening as appropriate and they also do any coordination between the different teams
they can be especially helpful because they usually have quite a lot of experience in the kubernetes community
um they can be especially helpful if as a team leader as a shadow you need them to kind of elevate a
request for something to happen that you need to be done to meet your deadlines they can be really helpful in that
regard this this release cycle for 1.19 uh taylor dolezal
is our release lead um and he's done an excellent job and you'll see a release coming out in august because
of the the work that he's done in leading these teams the emeritus advisor is typically someone who was
a release team lead in a previous release um so this this release it's tim pepper
and they really just helped their release team lead whenever they have questions about the way things should work
or just kind of help shoulder some of the burden if there's a lot of stuff going on so they can be especially helpful and
they're usually someone who is very very familiar with the kubernetes community release
engineering is a little bit different than all the other teams because it's its own sub project so as i mentioned sasha and
i both work on release engineering so these are the actual tools like the command line interface which is
called krell that allows us to actually do the operations to physically make the
release so that includes you know pushing new builds generating release notes
all things like that so that's kind of the engineering side of producing a release there's some really interesting stuff
that happens there there's always plenty of work around that tooling for folks that are looking to get involved and that actually has a cycle
in terms of membership outside of just a release cycle so typically if you're part of release engineering
you're part of that sub project for multiple cycles it's not really the typical shadow program
all right looking at bug triage ci signal on the rest these are all critical teams for making
sure different parts of the release are in place you can kind of guess by their name what they do each of these
teams typically has three to four shadows and then a lead who is usually a shadow before so
just to give you some context on my involvement this release cycle for 1.19 i am the ci
signal lead um for the past two releases 1.17 and 1.18 i was a shadow on that team
so it really is a good process for helping you to build up kind of acumen in your given area and
then you're able to move into a leadership role and share that same mentorship with folks that are falling behind you
but just to give a quick overview of each of these teams bug triage is going to help make sure
that any bugs that are raised as issues get addressed by the appropriate cigs in a timely fashion
ci signal is going to look at dashboards and tests and make sure that everything is passing
that is critical for release and if it's not they're going to make sure to find out whether it's a flaky test
a bug that needs to be corrected or whatever is happening to make sure that we're confident in the quality of the
release we're putting out there communications they kind of handle all the communication between the different
teams as well as the cncf and other community stakeholders
docs they're really important for that docs freeze that we were talking about so there's folks on the dock side that
supplement the technical review with kind of a grammatical review and content review and that sort of thing
um and i know from implementing a docs pr that this cycle that they are extremely helpful
as an engineer a lot of these folks are really really talented in how they
write documentation and they can help guide folks that are documenting the keps that they've
put into place speaking of caps nexus enhancements so these are folks that are tracking
new functionality that's being added to kubernetes for this cycle and making sure those are implemented in
a timely fashion and if not they'll get bumped to the next release and then finishing up is release notes
um it's been cool to see release notes working especially with release engineering lately to be able to generate some of
the notes that are produced so this is basically just telling consumers of kubernetes what new things are available um in
a new release and that includes the alpha beta rc releases etc so folks can know exactly what they're
getting what may be added what may be be removed in a release all right and lastly just
talking about the sig release shadowing program here i've already mentioned it quite a bit but i just want to encourage anyone

um there have been countless people who have been invested um in my growth and also um have expected
